sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: This is your news tonight, the headlines.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Forced to flee, now more than two and a half million people have escaped Ukraine for other countries.

sentences.sentence: The UN estimates that an additional two million people have been internally displaced because of the war.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Russian troops increased their intensive shelling across Ukraine.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02

sentences.sentence: THE UNITED NATIONS REFUGEE AGENCY SAYS MORE THAN 2.5 MILLION PEOPLE HAVE FLED UKRAINE AND AT LEAST 2 MILLION HAVE BEEN INTERNALLY DISPLACED, THIS SINCE RUSSIA INVADED. Ukraine and at least two million have been internally displaced this since Russia invaded now Russian troops have stepped up aerial bombardments for the first time airstrikes targeted the central eastern city of the Dnipro while troops around the capital Kiev are said to be regrouping and reports of shelling were confirmed in Lutsk and Ivano-Frankivsk cities in in the west of Ukraine, which are harboring thousands of people fleeing the conflict elsewhere in the country.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Now further east, hundreds of civilians were said to be inside a psychiatric hospital in the Kharkiv region as it was struck by Russian missiles.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Ukraine's defense minister claims that Russian armed forces have killed more civilians than soldiers.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: It's impossible to say how many days we will still need to free our land, but it's possible to say that we will do it because we strive for that.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: Because we have reached a strategic turning point.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: We are already moving towards our goal towards our victory this is a patriotic war war with a very stubborn enemy who does not pay attention to the thousands of the people and soldiers killed now let me bring in our correspondent Sasha bakulina who joins me now here in the studio Sasha more attacks, some new cities targeted as well.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Could you show us where these attacks have been taking place in Ukraine?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Certainly three cities targeted and shelled this morning.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: And let's start in the west of Ukraine.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: These are the cities of Lutsk and Ivano-Frankivsk.

sentences.sentence: Lutsk is very close to the border with Poland.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Ivano-Frankivsk to the border with Romania.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Now, these cities, they've been shelled for the first time. The city is very close to the borders of the European Union. Not only many Ukrainians are there as they fled from central Ukraine, from eastern and southern Ukraine, as you said, many, many more are crossing these regions and these cities every day when they're trying to flee the country and to go to the European Union to cross those borders. In both of these cases, these were the airfields that they were shelled this morning.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: And Russia confirmed this, saying that these were the targets there.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: The third city is Dnipro.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Now, Dnipro is the city in central Ukraine.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: It's a huge city.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: That's the first time it's been shelled today, this morning.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: They attack around 6 o'clock in the morning.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Three strikes hit the city with the buildings of the shoe factory the apartment block and the kindergarten nearby being targeted at least one person died Nipro F until this morning was also seen as a rather less dangerous I can't say safe place but less dangerous than other places in Ukraine.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Now, looking at the capital, Kiev, we've heard about those Russian troops regrouping today.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Yeah, that's according to the company Maxar Technologies and their satellite pictures.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Apparently, the troops are regrouping northwest of Kiev. You remember, this is the area with all the towns of Irpin, Bucha, and there is an airfield there, Hostomel.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: So towards Hostomel to Kiev, this is northwest from Ukraine's capital.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: There are pictures and proofs that there was a column of Russian troops that stayed there.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Now they dispersed and regrouped, and according to MaxRai technology, they are now about five kilometers closer to Kyiv than they were 24 hours ago.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: And this might mean that they are trying to reach Kyiv, the capital, in a different way.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Now, according to the presidential advisor, Aristovitch, Russian forces did not make any significant progress in the past 24 hours.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Now, the port city of Odessa there on the map, that city is also readying itself for a possible Russian advance.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Why is Odessa such an important city strategically? It is very, very important strategically indeed.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: It is the Black Sea coast here. And initially the troops went towards Odessa from Crimea. Now, according to the latest information by the mayor of Odessa and the head of the Mykolaiv region, those ships, they went back to their bases so which means that this is no longer going to be the attack from the sea.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Instead they do have information that they will try to get to Odessa from Mykolaiv region.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: As you know the troops are already in the region of Kherson, they are trying to advance to Mykolaiv and if they get to Mykolaiv this is when they can get towards Odessa because this way they will be able to surround Odessa and this will happen because of this region, because of the breakaway Transnistria, this is this territory of Moldova which is not recognized.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: This is the first and this is the example of a frozen war that happened in the very early 90s with the collapse of the Soviet Union. Transnistria is this territory here in yellow and there are permanently around 1,500 Russian troops called peacekeepers that are already there. Which means if there is movement from Kherson region towards Mykolaiv region, this would mean Odessa will be just surrounded from both sides.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: All right. Sasha Fakulina, thank you so much for explaining that to us.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Now the Russian president Vladimir Putin has ordered what the Kremlin is calling volunteer fighters to help pro-moscow fighters in Ukraine's Donbass

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: region your news reporter Galina Polonska now joins me live to discuss this Galina why does Russia need volunteers well that's a million dollar question pair we have heard from Russian officials that the special military operation that's how it is officially called in Russia is going on according to the plan and today Russia is actually saying that it will allow those foreign volunteers to help.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: And it is underlined that they will be helping for free.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: That's what Russians learned when they switched on their TVs, state TVs today.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: And so Vladimir Putin talking to the Russian Defense Minister Sergei Shoigu.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: russian's defense minister um sergey shaygu so sergey shaygu reported a quote that russia received a huge number of applications from various countries to come to the lugansk and daniel's people's republics to participate in what they consider to be the liberation movement and he underlined that most of the applications came from the middle east countries, 16,000 at least, and President Putin approved this idea.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Today, President's spokesman Dmitry Peskov was asked a lot of questions during the press briefing about those volunteers from other countries. Let's listen to what he had to say.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: what he had to say. If the Western world so welcomes the arrival of these motley mercenaries from different countries of the world, then there are also volunteers from our side who want to take part in this.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: The Ministry of Defence has a certain network of units that are in direct contact with the local population of Syria and a number of other countries.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: And Galina, the U.S. Security Council is meeting as we speak to discuss Russia's claims that the U.S. has been developing biological weapons in Ukraine what factual evidence did Russia present to back up these claims well so far we have just heard various statements of Russia's officials Moscow accuses the United States of sponsoring biological laboratories in laboratories iniv, Kyiv and Odessa.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: And the head of the Russian military's radiation, chemical and biological troops, protection troops Igor Kirillov said that according to their information, most of the documentation, biomaterials and equipment were evacuated to Lviv. And what Russia says is those labs were developing some kind of, working on some kind of dangerous pathogens to target Russians and other slabs.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Sergei Lavrov, the foreign minister of Russia, said that there were almost no doubts that those biological labs were working to develop ethnically targeted biological weapons well the us calls this a biological disinformation campaign and the white house said that it could be used for a false flag operation all right galena polonskaya there reporting on these developments at the u.n security council and now for more on russia's military campaign and strategy.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Let me bring in Samuel Ramani, who is an associate fellow at the British defense and security think tank, RUSI.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Samuel, I want to start with these warnings, these widespread Western warnings that Russia might be preparing to use chemical weapons.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: How real is this threat?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: Well, it doesn't surprise me at all if Russia were to use chemical weapons in Ukraine. Russia has a long history of claiming chemical weapons false flags. For example, in Chechnya in 1999, it claimed that the Chechen rebels were about to use chemical weapons in Grozny. But two, three years later, in 2002, Russia actually used chemical agents of their own to incapacitate Chechen militants and terrorists in a hostage crisis.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: And of course, the Russians have acquiesced to the use of chemical weapons by the Assad regime in Syria, and they've been claiming very similar chemical false flag like they did in Chechnya in Ukraine, with Sergei Shoigu warning the Americans could do it, and the United People's Republic in January warning that the Ukrainians could do it.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: So I'm fully on alert to see this happening and we've heard that Russia has confirmed that they use these thermal barrack bombs they're also accused of using cluster munition I want to ask you what's Putin's military strategy here I mean these very violent attacks on including civilian areas for example well it's a sign of the broader recalibration from Russia. The original goal was to launch a very fast blitz towards Kiev, overthrow Zelensky and install a puppet regime with somebody like Viktor Medvedchuk or an old crony of Viktor Yanukovych. But that strategy is clearly unraveled due to the strength of the Ukrainian resistance. So what the Russians have to do is start encircling major cities with siege tactics. And this is a lot more slow moving and also a lot more costly to civilian lives. And the use of costume munitions and the use of thermobaric bombs to basically bomb these cities into submission and encircle them is part of that strategy.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: And now he's even bringing in volunteers. That's what he's saying. He's ordered 16,000 volunteers to join the fight.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Why have both diplomatic talks and the Western sanctions on Russia failed to stop the war so far?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: Well, I think it's because Putin views this war as legacy-defining for him.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: He views it as a major way of restoring the Russians' fear of influence.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: And this is something that he's been steadily trying to do over the course of the past two decades, first in Georgia, then in Crimea, and now in a much bigger fashion in this war.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: So Putin is not going to give up just because of economic sanctions, which will take a while to bite the Russian economy and lead to the kind of mass protests that could threaten his regime and its hold on power, and diplomacy just seems to be not changing his mind either because he's committed to the war.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Samuel Bramady from the British security and defence think tank, RUSI, thank you so much there for joining us on Euronews tonight.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: And stay with us here on Euronews.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Much more news coming up. We'll be right back.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Welcome back to Euronews tonight.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Now, after two days of talks in Versailles, EU leaders have agreed to inject an additional 500 million euros into the military aid fund for Ukraine.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: The bloc took the unprecedented step of collectively supplying weapons to Ukraine last week, but Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy has said the bloc must do more after European leaders ruled out any sort of fast-track accession to the EU.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Now following the talks, President Macron gave this warning about the effect that the war could have on food supplies for both the EU and further afield. Whether it's wheat, maize or cereals, more broadly speaking, Ukraine and Russia are two very important producers.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Europe is already destabilized by the war.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: It will be even more so in 12 to 18 months because of what can't be planted right now in Ukraine.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Europe, and with it Africa, will be very deeply destabilized in terms of food.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: We therefore also need to prepare ourselves and re-evaluate our production strategies.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Now for more on this, let's head over to Versailles and speak to our correspondent Efi Kutsakusta, who joins us now live. Efi, what was the most important outcome from this meeting?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: what was the most important outcome from this meeting?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Yes, the EU leaders discussed all the urgent matters related to Russia's invasion of Ukraine, energy, defence spending, the possibility of imposing further sanctions on Russia, and of course Ukraine's bid to join the EU as soon as possible.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: I would say that there was no concrete result as expected as this. I would say that there was no concrete result as expected as this was an informal summit. The most tangible result was the agreement to expand the European peace facility by another 500 million euros in order to support military Ukraine with more defensive lethal weapons. When it comes to the debate, the longest debate during these two days was Ukraine's bid to join the EU. There the leaders last night discussed it for three hours and this matter has proved to be quite divisive. We have on one side the Eastern European countries that want a clear message, a clear path towards the European perspective for Ukraine and to speed up the process, while others, namely the Netherlands, Germany and France, that they are not really sure that this is the right time when Ukraine is at war to give it a timeline for an EU membership.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: And of course, what has been agreed was a consensus, a compromise in this statement, saying clearly that the political message is that Ukraine belongs to the European family and that the process will be fast in order for the Commission to assess the request, but not a clear timeline, no fast-track process. Ukraine has to follow the steps that all countries are following in order to get an EU candidacy and in the long term, an EU membership.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Now, Viktor Orban, Hungary's leader, he said in a video on his Facebook page that the EU would not sanction Russian oil or gas and this was to ensure Hungary's energy supply.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: How divided would you say that the EU is on this demand for Russian energy exports it is because not all countries actually are they dependent at the same level on Russian gas and oil there is always the bloc of the countries including the Baltics or Poland that won't tougher sanctions the most the most the toughest sanctions on Russia including this ban but others are saying that this is not the time to do it because still the EU imports almost 40% of its gas and oil from Russia. So in the short term they cannot completely cut contracts. It's not only Hungary, it's also Germany and other countries and they are trying to find ways, alternatives in order to boost energy independence.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Ursula von der Leyen said it clearly that the EU Commission will come up with a new proposal by mid-May with alternatives and ways in order to phase out dependence on Russian gas by 2027.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Efi Koutsoukousta, live for us at Versailles. Thank you so much for that, Efi.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_13
sentences.sentence: F equals acoustic was alive for us at Versailles thank you so much for that Effie now tech giant meta says it will allow violent speech against invading Russian forces following this war in Ukraine here's Matthew and the cube with more Matthew well pair this move by meta the big tech company that owns Facebook it certainly caused a stir a statement confirmed that they have made a temporary decision to allow certain forms of political expression that would normally have been banned under Facebook's policies. Users can now post things like death to Russian invaders, hate speech directed against even Russian soldiers, President Vladimir Putin or his Belarusian counterpart Alexander Lukashenko will be allowed. And according to Reuters, this will apply to Facebook users not just in Russia, who are now accessing Facebook via privately protected browsers, but also Facebook users in other Eastern European countries.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_13
sentences.sentence: Now this is certainly a shift because up until now, as you can see on Facebook's policies, they do not allow violent speech or support for violence that is directed against any individual or group.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_13
sentences.sentence: And this move, as you can imagine, has generated a strong reaction from Moscow.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_13
sentences.sentence: The Russian embassy in the United States released a statement on Twitter calling on American authorities to take action against Meta over what it has described as extremist activities.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_13
sentences.sentence: The country's state communications watchdog has also now restricted Instagram after an order by prosecutors. Of course a similar move was made against Facebook earlier this month and on top of that Russian citizens are already facing lengthy prison sentences if they are deemed to have shared intentionally fake information about the Russian military.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_13
sentences.sentence: But it isn't just in Moscow that this move by Meta has generated a reaction.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_13
sentences.sentence: The United Nations Human Rights Office has also said that it raises some concerns.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_13
sentences.sentence: Even though Meta says hate speech will still not be allowed against Russian citizens, or Russia as a country in general, there are fears from analysts that this new policy will eventually descend into more widespread anti-Russia hate a country where some citizens of course have not sub voiced their support for the war in Ukraine and pair it's also worth noting that when it comes to Twitter they have not taken any similar move for now they are keeping in place their existing policies when it comes to hate speech and violent content online all right right, Matthew in the Cube. Thank you, Matthew.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Still to come here on the program, Russian troops in Ukraine are mounting a ferocious attack on the country, but not all Russians in Ukraine are in favor of the war. Up next, we catch up with Andrei, who lives in Kiev and who strongly opposes the invasion. Stay with us.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: and who strongly opposes the invasion.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Stay with us.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Welcome back to Eager News Tonight.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: We're going to take a look at Russians living in Ukraine now, many of whom have found themselves in a difficult position since the war began.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: For some, their homeland's invasion of its neighbor has been devastating, as Mark Armstrong reports.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: Andrei Sidokin is a Russian citizen but lives in the Ukrainian capital Kyiv.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: He's one of many in the same position who flatly reject the Kremlin's illegal and brutal invasion. He wants to help defend Ukraine and is trying.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: I've already been to the military enlistment office five times, but they sent me back precisely because I have a Russian passport.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: I tried to somehow get through in another way, and I went to Azov, but so far to no avail.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: That's why I volunteer.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: These are uneasy times for Russians living in Ukraine.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: Sasha Alexeeva lives in Lviv, a city near the Polish border.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: She says she's ashamed of what Russia is doing and says the invasion has broken her heart, and many like her.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: SASHA ALEXEEVA, Russian Resident, It's difficult for people who have been in Ukraine for a long time without legal grounds.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: I know people who have been living here for 10 years without legal grounds, and now they can't leave anywhere, even if they wanted to. And the suspicion on the part of the police, the security services, of course, is significant for them.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: Those suspicions create a double sense of helplessness among those with Russian passports and Ukrainian hearts. Andrei Sidokin will do what he can to protect the people and the country that he loves.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: ANDREI SIDOKIN, Russian President- First of all, this is also my home, like for the rest of the people in Kyiv.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: And I also have to and want to protect it.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: And besides, if this happens, God forbid, that Russian troops enter here, I would like to meet them with weapons in my hands and not empty-handed. Besides, if this happens, God forbid, that Russian troops enter here, I would like to meet them with weapons in my hands and not empty-handed." But for now, all he can do is volunteer.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: And we leave you with a note comment from Kiev, where volunteers have been feeding thousands of soldiers and civilians from a roadside kitchen.
